content.text: Hordes
A Horde is any group of weak enemies acting as a single unit. One activation, one roll — but size grants bonuses.
Horde Size Bonus to Accuracy Bonus Damage Dice
Killing Horde members reduces the group’s size, shrinking their bonuses.
Hordes are dangerous but don’t steal the clock. A swarm of 15 rift-goblins takes one activation, rolls once (with +3/+3 bonuses), and resolves. No tracking 15 individual turns.
Range Bands
Range Band Description Squares (if using grid)
Adjacent Within arm’s reach. 0-1 squares Melee range.
Close A few steps away. 2-3 squares Thrown weapon range.
Short Across a room. Pistol 4-8 squares effective range.
Medium Down a corridor. Rifle 9-16 squares effective range.
Long Across a warehouse. 17-30 squares Sniper effective range.
Extreme Barely visible. Maximum 31+ squares engagement distance. ----------------------- ----------------------- -----------------------
Weapons have range brackets that impose accuracy penalties outside their optimal range:
Weapon Type Optimal Range Penalty Outside
Melee                   Adjacent                Cannot attack beyond Adjacent
Thrown                  Close-Short             -2 accuracy per band outside
Pistol                  Short                   -2 per band beyond Short
Rifle                   Medium                  -2 per band beyond Medium
Moving between range bands: Moving 1 range band = 1 AP. Moving from Adjacent to Short = 2 AP. Plan your positioning — AP spent moving is AP not spent attacking.
Throwables & Area Effects
Grenades, bombs, and other thrown items follow different rules than weapon attacks. You're targeting an area, not a person — no accuracy roll required.
Using a Throwable

• Cost: 1 AP (Use Item action) • Range: Close (unless noted otherwise) • Targeting: No accuracy roll. Pick a point in range and throw. • Friendly fire: Yes. Grenades don't pick sides. If allies are in the blast area, they're affected too.
Adjacent Cluster

Many throwables affect an Adjacent cluster — all creatures within Adjacent range (arm's reach) of the detonation point. This typically means 2-4 creatures who are grouped together. The GM determines who's in the cluster based on positioning.

• Creatures spread across a room are NOT in one cluster — they're at Close range from each other, not Adjacent.  • Two enemies fighting your frontliner? Same cluster.  • A horde packed in a doorway? Same cluster.  • Your ally who charged into that horde? Also in the cluster. Plan accordingly.
Dodge Roll (Damage Throwables)

When a throwable deals direct damage (Frag Grenade, Incendiary Grenade, Rift Flare, Concussion Charge), each target in the area may attempt a Reflex check (2d6 + Reflex bonus) vs DC 9 as a free reaction.

rows: Half damage (round each die down before armor). Any secondary conditions from the throwable (Burn, etc.) don't apply.
Full damage. All secondary conditions apply.

content.text: Modifiers:

rows: -2 to dodge roll (already on the ground — hard to dive)
Automatic half damage (no roll needed). Does not stack with a successful dodge — half is the floor.

content.text: Condition Saves (Effect Throwables)

Throwables that inflict conditions without damage (Flashbang, Smoke Grenade, Toxin Cloud, EMP Charge, Glue Bomb) use their own listed save — typically Grit DC 7. This is a separate mechanic from the dodge roll. You're not diving away, you're enduring the effect.
One roll per throwable. Damage throwables → Reflex DC 9 (dodge the blast, avoid secondary conditions). Effect-only throwables → listed save (resist the condition). Never both.
Knockback

When an effect says "Knockback X range band(s)", the target is pushed X range bands directly away from the source. Knockback is forced movement — no resistance roll, no save. The physics don't care about your opinion.

• Knockback does NOT provoke Opportunity Attacks (the target isn't choosing to move). • If knocked into a solid obstacle (wall, pillar, vehicle), the target stops and takes 1d6 impact damage (ignores armor). • If knocked off a ledge or into a hazard, the target suffers the appropriate falling/hazard damage. • Knockback moves the target even if they're Prone.
Condition Interactions
Multiple conditions stack independently. Being Stunned, Prone, and Hexed at the same time is rough but mechanically straightforward — apply all effects.

rows: Reapplying a condition refreshes its duration. You can't be "double Stunned" — but the timer resets.
These stack infinitely. Each application adds another stack. Different from conditions.
Clearing a condition removes its effects immediately. Standing from Prone (1 AP) removes -2 Evasion that instant.
Stunned/Grappled targets cannot dodge AoE and automatically fail Reflex-based saves. Grit saves are still rolled.
Some abilities grant condition immunity (e.g., Last Bastion). Immune means the condition never applies — not that it applies and is removed.

content.text: Rift Casting in Combat

Rift patterns follow the same attack rules as weapons — roll accuracy (Interface bonus), compare to Evasion, roll damage on hit. The difference: rift patterns cost toxicity and have enhanced damage profiles to compensate.

Rift patterns have Penetration 1 — they ignore 1 point of the target’s Armor per damage die. Magic finds gaps that steel can’t. Additionally, rift patterns roll larger damage dice than their physical equivalents.

The cost is real. Each pattern cast adds 2-5 toxicity. A Channeler who casts every turn for 5 turns accumulates 10-25 toxicity — potentially hitting the 50% bracket and suffering debuffs that persist long after the fight ends. Physical fighters swing for free. Casters pay in poison.
See the Rift Casting section for pattern lists, toxicity costs, and casting rules.
Conditions & Status Effects
Effect Stacks
Some weapons and abilities apply stacking effects to targets. These build over multiple hits and trigger payoffs at thresholds.
Effect Per Stack Threshold Payoff
Poison 1 damage at start of At 5 stacks: damage target’s turn doubles to 2 per stack per turn
Glitch -1 to accuracy roll At 3 stacks: one random augment disabled for the encounter
Marked +1 accuracy bonus for At 4 stacks: crits allies attacking this against this target are target automatic (any hit becomes a crit)

Effect weapons (Toxic Needle, Neural Probe, etc.) deal negligible direct damage but apply stacks on every hit. With d12 or d10 accuracy dice and 1 AP cost, they hit often and stack fast. Five needle hits per turn = 5 poison stacks = threshold reached in one turn.

A contractor applying Poison 5 to a boss means the boss takes 10 damage per turn (2 per stack at threshold) for the rest of the fight. The Needle’s direct damage is a joke. The 5 stacks of Poison are not.

Toxicity in Combat
Toxicity is primarily a long-term concern, but it has combat-relevant thresholds:
Toxicity % Threshold Effect
25%+ Glowing — Stealth checks at -2. You’re visibly irradiated.
50%+ Leaking — Allies within Adjacent range gain +1 toxicity per round.
70%+ Unstable — Involuntary discharges: at end of each combat round, 20% chance of 1d4 damage to a random adjacent creature (ally or enemy).
90%+ Critical — All checks at -2. Scanners flag you immediately.
100% Harvest Threshold — Corps are coming. See Scars & Toxicity document. ----------------------------------- -----------------------------------
Leech tree contractors have augments that modify these thresholds. See the Leech Augment Tree for details on Burn/Bleed mechanics.
Effect Weapons
Effect weapons are specialist tools — not for killing, but for setting up kills.
Weapon Accuracy AP Damage Effect (Every Hit)
Toxic Needle   d12            1              1d2            +1 Poison stack
Neural Probe   d10            1              1d4            +1 Glitch stack
Tracker Dart   d10            2              1d2            +1 Marked stack

At 1-2 AP per attack, an effect specialist can apply 3-5 stacks per turn. Poison threshold (5 stacks) can be reached in a single turn by a dedicated needle wielder. Pair an effect specialist with a heavy hitter — one sets up debuffs, the other delivers the killing blow.
Sample Combat: Putting It Together
Setup: 4 contractors enter a rift cave. 6 Rift-Goblins (Horde, size 6) and 1 Rift-Stalker (Elite) guard the objective.
Activations: Players have 4. Enemies have 2 (Horde = 1, Elite = 1). Players have more activations — they’ll get 2 consecutive turns at the end.

Round 1: Player Side: Chrome Brawler (Chrome 7, +3 bonus) charges the Horde. • Move Adjacent to Horde (1 AP). Swing Heavy Axe (4 AP). Total: 5 AP spent. • Accuracy: d6, roll 4. +3 bonus = 7. +2 conditional (moved toward target) = 9. Horde Evasion 3. Hit! • Damage: 3d10, roll 8, 5, 9. Horde Armor 1: 7, 4, 8 = 19 damage. • 3 goblins go down. Horde drops from 6 to 3. Bracket drops from +2/+2 to +1/+1. Enemy Side: Horde attacks the Brawler. • Accuracy: d8 + 1 (size bonus). Roll 5 + 1 = 6. Brawler Evasion 3 (Heavy Plate cap). Hit. • Damage: 1d6 + 1 bonus die = 2d6, roll 4, 3. Armor 6: 0, 0 = 0 damage. Heavy plate absorbs everything. Player Side: Sniper (Reflex 8, +4 bonus) sets up and fires at the Rift-Stalker. • No movement. Fire Sniper Rifle (5 AP). Total: 5 AP spent. • Accuracy: d6, roll 6 — NATURAL MAX. CRITICAL HIT. • Auto-hit regardless of Evasion. Double damage dice. • Damage: 3d10 × 2 = 6d10, roll 9, 7, 4, 10, 6, 8. Stalker Armor 3: 6, 4, 1, 7, 3, 5 = 26 damage. • The Stalker staggers. Enemy Side: Rift-Stalker charges the Sniper. • Moves 2 range bands (2 AP). Attacks with Rift Claws (3 AP). Total: 5 AP. • Accuracy: d8, roll 6. +3 bonus = 9. Sniper Evasion 5. Hit. • Damage: 2d8, roll 7, 5. Armor 2: 5, 3 = 8 damage. The Sniper is hurt but standing. Player Side: Needle Specialist (Reflex 6, +3 bonus) targets the Stalker. • Move Adjacent (1 AP). Stab with Toxic Needle four times (4 AP). Total: 5 AP. • Four accuracy rolls (d12 each): 8, 3, 11, 6. All +3 = 11, 6, 14, 9. Stalker Evasion 4. All four Hit. • Direct damage: negligible. Poison stacks: 4. One more hit reaches threshold. Player Side: Channeler (Interface 7, +3 bonus) finishes the Horde. • Rift Bolt at the remaining 3 goblins (3 AP). Move to cover (1 AP). Spare 1 AP. • Accuracy: d8, roll 5. +3 = 8. Horde Evasion 3. Hit. • Damage: 2d10, roll 7, 9. Armor 1, minus Pen 1 = Armor 0: 7, 9 = 16 damage. • Horde wiped. +3 toxicity for the Channeler.
Round 2: The Stalker is poisoned (4 stacks), badly wounded, and facing four contractors. One more needle hit crosses the threshold. The fight is effectively over. Total combat: 2 rounds.
Skill Checks in Combat

Not everything in a fight is swinging a weapon. Sometimes you need to hide behind cover, stabilize a dying ally, kick open a jammed door, or hack an enemy’s augments mid-fight. These use the same skill check resolution as out of combat.
The Roll
2d6 + Stat Bonus + Skill Modifier
Result Outcome
10+ Full success
7-9 Partial success (complication, reduced effect, or cost)
Using a skill in combat costs 1 AP. You can still attack and move with remaining AP.

Gated Skills
Skills marked with gating (Hacking, Medicine, Crafting, Rift Lore)
cannot be attempted at all without at least T1 training.
Untrained characters attempting non-gated skills roll at -2 to the check.
Contested Checks
When a skill check is directly opposed by another creature, both sides roll. Higher result wins. Ties go to the acting party.
Quick Reference Card
Attack Flow

1. Roll weapon accuracy die + stat bonus 2. Apply weapon conditional modifiers 3. Total ≥ Evasion = Hit 4. Hit → roll weapon damage dice 5. Subtract Armor from each damage die 6. Total remaining = damage dealt
Critical Hit
Natural max on accuracy die → Auto-hit + double damage dice
Action Points
5 AP per turn. Attack = 1-5 AP. Move = 1 AP/band. Item = 1 AP. Skill = 1 AP. Defend = 2 AP. Overwatch = Weapon AP + 1. Grapple = 2 AP. Suppress = 3 AP.
Quick Actions (Free)
Drop item, speak, toggle passive, fall prone.
Reactions (1/round)
Opportunity Attack: d8+stat acc, 1d6+stat dmg (fixed, not weapon). Triggers when enemy leaves melee range.
Overwatch
Weapon AP + 1, set on your turn. Next enemy moving in range triggers full weapon attack.
Grapple
2 AP, Chrome vs Chrome. Grappled = can’t move, -1 Evasion. Escape = 1 AP + Chrome check.
Shove
1 AP, Chrome vs Chrome. Push 1 band OR knock Prone.
At 0 HP
Gain +1 Scar → Roll 1d20 vs Death DC → Survive at 50% HP or Flatline
Dual Wield
Each weapon costs its own AP. Off-hand -1 accuracy. -1 Evasion.
Initiative
Highest Reflex goes first. Alternate sides. Players pick their own order.
Skill Check
2d6 + Stat Bonus + Skill Modifier → 10+ Full / 7-9 Partial / 6- Failure. Costs 1 AP in combat.
